recipeIngredient: 1 piece kombu (dried kelp) (5 x 12 cm per piece)
15 g katsuobushi (dried bonito flakes) (skip for vegetarian/vegan)
1 tablespoon usukuchi (light-colored) soy sauce (can substitute regular soy sauce)
½ teaspoon Diamond Crystal kosher salt
4 slices narutomaki (fish cakes) (optional; skip for vegetarian/vegan)
2 servings udon noodles (500 g frozen or 180 g dry udon noodles)

text.content: Gather all ingredients. For best flavor, make dashi from scratch.
Soak 1 piece of kombu in 600 ml water for at least 30 minutes (skip if no time).
Transfer kombu and water to a saucepan and slowly bring to a boil over medium-low heat.
Remove kombu just before boiling. For non-vegetarian/vegan, add 15 g katsuobushi and bring to a boil again.
Once boiling, simmer for 15 seconds, turn off heat. Let katsuobushi sink for 10-15 minutes, then strain.
In a saucepan, combine 540 ml dashi, 1 tablespoon mirin, 1 teaspoon sugar, 1 tablespoon usukuchi soy sauce, and ½ teaspoon kosher salt. Bring to a boil, then turn off heat or simmer low.
Squeeze liquid from 4 Inari age. Thinly slice 1 green onion and 4 narutomaki slices (3 mm thick).
Boil water for 2 servings (500 g frozen or 180 g dry) udon noodles. Reheat frozen udon for 1 minute; cook dry noodles as per package.
Drain noodles, shaking off excess water.
Divide noodles into bowls. Pour hot broth over. Top with Inari age, narutomaki, and green onions. Sprinkle shichimi togarashi (optional).
